advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (NOV. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The Acorn Atom is a definitive personal computer. Simple to build, simple to operate. A powerful, full facility computer with all the features you would expect.<br> Just connect the assembled computer to any domestic TV and power source and you are ready to begin. (Power requirement: 8V at 800mA). There is an ATOM power unit available. <br><br> Free with every ATOM, kit or built, is a computer manual. The first section explains and teaches you BASIC, the language that most personal computers and the ATOM operate in. The instructions are simple and learning quickly becomes a pleasure. You'll soon be writing your own programs. The second section is a reference manual giving a full description of the ATOM's facilities and how to use them. Both sections arE fully illustrated with example programs. <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM includes:</b><br> HARDWARE<br> . Full-sized QWERTY keyboard. 6502 Microprocessor. Rugged injection-moulded case. 2K RAM. 8K HYPER-ROM<br> . 23 integrated circuits and sockets. Audio cassette interface. UHF TV output. Full assembly instructions<br> SOFTWARE<br> . 32-bit arithmetic (:i: 2,000,000,000). High speed execution. 43 standard/extended BASIC commands. Variable length strings (up to 256 characters) . String manipulation functions. 27 x 32 bit integer variables<br> . 27 additional arrays. Random number function. PUT and GET byte. WAIT command for timing. DO-UNTIL construction . Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR) . Link t machine - code routines. PLOT commands, DRAW and MOVE <br><br> <b>The ATOM modular concept</b><br> The ATOM has been designed to grow with you. As you build confidence and knowledge you can add more components. For instance the next stage might be to increase the ROM and RAM on the basic ATOM from 8K + 2K to 12K + 12K respectively. This will give you a direct printer drive, floating point mathematics, scientific and trigonometric functions, high resolution graphics.<br> From there you can expand indefinitely. Acorn have produced an enormous range of compatible PCB's which can be added to your original computer. For instance: A module to give red, green and blue colour signals Teletext VDU card (for Prestel and Ceefax information) An in-board connector for a communications loop interface - any number of ATOMs may be linked to each other or to a master system with mass storage/hard copy facility. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 68 years old, taunt Rose discovered that she was an exceptionally gifted child"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an official advert from Hewlett-Packard. It says "The easy touch".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8086 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1982, Seattle Computer provided the 8086 version of the Gazelle with a free set of software: Microsoft MS-DOS, GW-Basic and the Perfect Writer word processor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pong-story.com" target="_blank">www.pong-story.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>

computer.description:
The Apple Macintosh SE was launched in 1987 at same time as the Macintosh II. It was an enhanced version of the Macintosh 128 and the Macintosh Plus. It had almost the same specifications as the latter, and unlike the Mac plus, it had an extension slot (which was not compatible with the NUBUS slots of the Macintosh II).
A little trivia: the ROM used only 89 KB of the available 256 KB. So to fill the chip, Apple put the photos of the development team into the ROM. To see these photos, press the debug button then type: G 41D89A.
The Mac 128, the 512k, the 512KE (same but with an 800K floppy drive), and the SE have the signatures of their developers molded as engravings on the inside of the case at the rear. _______________________

emulator.description: Basilisk II is an Open Source 68k Macintosh emulator. Good emulator, runs on several platforms, even Amiga
emulator.name: Basilisk II

emulator.description: Mini vMac, a spin off of the program vMac, emulates a Macintosh Plus and Macintosh SE. So far it works on Macintosh OS, Microsoft Windows, and the X Window System.
emulator.name: Mini vMac

computer.keyboard: Typewriter style, 84 keys with numeric keypad
computer.media: One or Two 3.5'' disk-drives, 20 to 80 MB HDD
computer.name: MACINTOSH SE
computer.ports: Centronics, ADB (2 : Keyboard, mouse), RS232/422, Internal expansion slot (96-pin Eurodin)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Connectors, from left to right:<br> • 2 ADB connectors for keyboard and mouse<br> • SCSI connector for external HDD<br> • Parallel printer connector<br> • 2 serial ports (Printer and modem)<br> • Sound output jack</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 20 MB Hard disk drive<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Motherboard<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 100W switching power supply unit<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Video board</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Internal SCSI connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Internal floppy-disk connectors<br> <b>(3)</b> SCSI chip<br> <b>(4)</b> Apple Desktop Bus chip<br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel chip (VIA)<br> <b>(6)</b> 256 KB ROM chips. Holds system routines<br> <b>(7)</b> Motorola 68000 processor<br> <b>(8)</b> Peripheral card slot (96-pin Eurodin)<br> <b>(9)</b> 1 MB RAM in four 256k SIMM modules (could be replaced with 1 MB modules)<br> <b>(10)</b> Custom gate array chip<br> <b>(11)</b> Disk management chip (IWM)<br> <b>(12)</b> Serial chip (SCC) and drivers<br> <b>(13)</b> Sound chip<br> </blockquote>
